0.text: It can be exhausting when your children have too much energy or can't focus on one thing. Sometimes, your children need opportunities to be very active and run around to help them be calm afterwards.

36.text: Would like suggestions for active and calm things to do with your child?

62.text: Help your baby learn through play.  Put objects in your baby’s grasping hand, show them different materials, and answer when they ‘talk’ to you.

88.text: Remember that you’re in charge of what they eat, but not how much. Newborns have stomach the size of a grape! They need to eat often (sometimes in the middle of the night.

122.text: It’s important to build trust around eating, especially as your baby starts on solid food. Let them know you are listening to their wishes in the eating department. They’ll be ravenous again soon!

155.text: Do you need some ideas of what you can do with your child?

170.text: Check to see why your baby is in a bad mood. Are they tired or hungry? Or maybe they are not feeling well? Or maybe they need some more loving attention. Be a reassuring presence for your baby when they are having a difficult day.

215.text: Unfortunately, your baby will go through phases for the next 2 years of sleeping poorly. Try wearing your baby close to you, feeding them and carrying them in a sling. And hang in there, remember it’s a phase. You and your baby will get through it together!

262.text: Your baby will cry as soon as a caregiver’s attention is diverted and are cranky as well as clingy. Prioritise being there for them and give them physical contact when needed.

293.note: This is an argument and it may be used to identify a corresponding quick reply

295.note: This is an argument and it may be used to identify a corresponding quick reply

297.text: Pay close attention to your baby in case they try something dangerous! Just because they are able to play on their own now, doesn’t mean you can look away for long. Redirect mischievous behaviours into practice waving, imitation games, singing and moving games and pretending to talk on the phone!

347.text: Try to stay calm and support your toddler as they move through the tantrum. Your priority is to ensure that they don’t hurt themselves. Don’t add to your child’s anger by shouting and showing angry emotions. This won’t help.

386.text: Babies are much more likely to want to do things if you make the activity fun and playful. Patience is also a must. Take a deep breath if you notice yourself getting frustrated by your baby.

422.text: Would you like to learn more?

454.text: Your baby or toddler may sometimes want something that they cannot have. If they start whining, first check to see if there is something wrong (are they actually hungry or tired)? If they continue, try to redirect their attention to something else. You should also try to ignore their behaviour while attending to them for comfort and support

940.text: Today's Tip is about how we can help to protect our children.

952.text: The idea of talking to children about abuse can be scary. We don't know what to say. But there are some simple things can help them understand when it is not OK to be touched, and that they can tell you if something ever happens.

998.text: When you are walking or doing something together it can be easier to chat.

1013.text: Do you want to learn more about how to protect your child from abuse?

1061.text: Here are 3 things that you should make sure your child knows to protect them from abuse:

1095.text: Type "1" to 3" to learn more about these tips. Type "N" to stop this tip.

1111.note: This is an argument and it may be used to identify a corresponding quick reply

1113.text: Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

1125.text: The parts of their body that go under people's underwear or a swimsuit are private parts. It is not OK for other people to touch or to ask to look at them, or ask them to look at or touch theirs.

1172.text: If someone tries to touch your children's private parts they must say NO and tell a grown up that they trust.

1201.text: Your children should tell you if there is a secret that makes them feel worried. You will not be angry. Only nice secrets - like a surprise birthday party - should be kept secret.

1236.text: Do you want to go back and learn more about how to protect your child from abuse?

1285.text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Supporting your child through a crisis will also teach them how to support others in difficult times. Good for you!

1316.text: Remember you can always type "Help" if you ever want more parenting tips or support. You can also change the type of messages you receive for an older or younger child. Just select "Tech Support." Chat to you later!

1355.text: Today's Tip is about how we can support our teens when they experience really difficult situations.

1372.text: When our children share difficult experiences with us, we may initially get angry because we are afraid for them. But that is when we need to stay calm, listen, and be open.

1499.text: We are models of our children's behaviour. If we practice keeping safe distances, handwashing and treat others with compassion, our children and teenagers will do the same.

1531.text: They like to be like me and you,

1539.text: What you do and what you say,

1546.text: Will help to shape them everyday!

1552.text: Routines will make your children feel safe and secure. Try to have regular mealtimes and bedtimes. Remember to schedule One-on-One time with your children, too!

1577.text: Did you know that teens actually like having responsibilities? It makes them feel more independent and grown up. Allow your teen to choose a special job that helps out.

1606.text: As your teen shows more responsibility, you can also give them extra privileges. Try to share responsibilities equally amongst women/men and girls/boys. Praise your teen whenever they do their job!

1636.text: When you teach your children about safe distancing, you keep your whole family safe. You keep others safe, too!

1655.text: You can even make safe distancing into a game where children earn points for keeping at least 1 metre away from others in public. The one with the most points can win a simple, free reward like extra One-on-One Time

1695.text: Today's Tip is about how we can support our children when they are feeling sad, scared, angry, and confused.
